title: Oil Shoots up After Attacks
text:
PSG Wealth Daily Investment Update, 17 September 2019

The local market started the week in the green, reaching a seven-week high, after banks rose by more than 3% and Sasol (JO: ) by 9.85%, boosted by the oil price jump. At the closing bell, the All Share was up by 1.28%.Wall Street opened lower on Monday, regardless of the surge in energy shares, because of investor concerns around global growth after the weekend’s attacks in Saudi Arabia. Shortly after the JSE closed, the was 0.60% in the negative.Despite the rise in oil shares on Monday, European markets fell as weak Chinese economic data and the attack on Saudi Arabian crude facilities fuelled global growth fears. At the end of trade, the stood 0.58% in the red.On Monday, Asian indices were weighed down by negative Chinese economic data and the weekend’s escalating protests in Hong Kong. The closed down 1.03%.The Index was closed due to a public holiday.The local currency took a knock on Monday after the oil price surged; as an oil importer, an increase in oil prices will negatively impact the South African currency. At 18h45, the rand traded at R14.63/$.Investors flocked to safe-haven assets on Monday, boosting gold by over 1%, after the attacks in Saudi Arabia “fuelled concerns of a further escalation in Middle East tensions”. At 18h45, an ounce of traded at $1 503.92.Oil prices rose by almost 20% at one point on Monday because of the drone attack on Saudi Arabian crude facilities over the weekend. The attack shut down 5% of the world’s crude output. At 18h45, a barrel of traded at $65.85.
